title: Duterte refutes red-tagging but warns that rebels, even women fighters, will likely die in clashes with gov't troops.(National)(Rodrigo Duterte)
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1147211054938</sequenceId>
			<id>43742692632</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Duterte refutes red-tagging but warns that rebels, even women fighters, will likely die in clashes with gov't troops.(National)(Rodrigo Duterte)</title>
			<content>Communist rebels, particularly women fighters, will likely die in a clash with the government troops, President Duterte declared Monday.

President Rodrigo Roa Duterte talks to the people after holding a meeting with the Inter-Agency Task Force on the Emerging Infectious Diseases (IATF-EID) core members at the Malacanang Golf (Malago) Clubhouse in Malacanang Park, Manila on November 30, 2020. (KARL NORMAN ALONZO / PRESIDENTIAL PHOTO / FILE PHOTO / MANILA BULLETIN)

The President voiced confidence about the chances of defeat of the rebels in a military encounter after mentioning the death of Jevilyn Cullamat in his televised address Monday night.

"O kita mo 'yung kay Cullamat. O 'di anak niya mismo, babae pa. Ah sigurado patay 'yan. Babae ilaban mo sa sundalo? Ah patay sigurado. (Look at what happened to Cullamat. Her own daughter was involved, a woman. Why let a woman fight a soldier? She will certainly die)," he said in his remarks.

Duterte had earlier identified the Makabayan bloc as among the legal fronts of the communist rebel group, saying they were part of an alleged grand conspiracy to bring down the government.

But the President told the rebels dreaming of "utopia" that this was not possible.

"You dream of a country, gusto ninyo ano, 'yung utopia (you want utopia). It's not possible here. You have to realize that," he said.

"Walang red-tagging-red tagging. Talagang komunista kayo, talagang kasama kayo (You are really communists, you are part of the group). Time will come," he added.

Jevilyn, the 22-year-old daughter of Bayan Muna party-list Rep. Eufemia Cullamat, was killed in a clash between the military and New People's Army (NPA) rebels in Surigao del Sur on Nov. 28. She reportedly served as a medic of the rebels.

The military released a photo showing the deceased rebel alongside seized weapons, triggering an uproar from her family. Cullamat admitted that her daughter joined the NPA to fight the injustices against the indigenous peoples but asked the military not to use her remains as a trophy.

In his speech, the President warned about the possible extinction of the Lumads if these indigenous peoples will support the communist movement before he addressed the killing of Jevilyn.

He told the Lumads to return to their homes, saying they were only being deceived by the NPA rebels.

"I think 75 percent, at least in Mindanao, mga Lumad. Kayong mga Lumad, umuwi kayo. Sabihin ninyo sa mga tao ninyo na niloloko lang sila ng --- niloloko ng ano, ng NPA talaga. Totoo 'yan. Ang maraming namatay ang Lumad (I think 75 percent, at least in Mindanao, are Lumads. You Lumads go home. Tell your people they are being fooled by the NPA. That's the truth. Many Lumads have died)," he said.

"So if this thing goes on, the Lumads, 'yung native na Pilipino talaga, it will become an extinct tribe. 'Pag hindi kayo --- 'pag hindi kayo huminto diyan, lumayas, forever kayong wanted. Eh sabi nga ni Parlade sa Armed Forces, delikado kayong mamatay kayo sama-sama kayo diyan (If this thing goes on, the Lumads, the really native Filipinos, it will become an extinct tribe. If you don't stop, if you don't leave, you will be wanted by authorities forever. Like what Parlade of the Armed Forces said, it's dangerous. You might die if you join the rebels)," he said.

Prior to his remarks about Jevilyn, the President alleged that the Makabayan, Bayan, and Gabriela are among the front organizations of the Communist Party of the Philippines-New People's Army.

The Makabayan bloc in the House of Representatives is composed of six party-list lawmakers from Bayan Muna, ACT Teachers, Gabriela Women's Party, and Kabataan.

"We are not tagging you. We are identifying you as communist. It's a grand conspiracy. So the liability of a mere soldier, is the liability of all the members of the organizations, iyong mga front (those are the front organizations)," Duterte said.

A visibly annoyed President also singled out Bayan Muna party-list Rep. Carlos Zarate in his latest rebuke, calling him a communist. "You are friends with the NPA, you are co-conspirators. Komunista ka, adre, matagal na alam ko (You are a communist. I've known it for a long time)," he said.

CAPTION(S):</content>

display_version: Suspected al Shabaab Militants Attack Garissa Police Base Suspected al Shabaab militants stormed a police base before opening fire, leaving one officer nursing injuries.

triaging_data.summary: 12/02/2020: Assailants opened fire on Amuma police patrol base in Fafi, Garissa county, Kenya. One police officer was killed, one officer was wounded, and one other was reported missing and their whereabouts are unknown. The assailants also bombed the base’s armory using a rocket-propelled grenade. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab. (adding Xinhua sv3 http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-12/02/c_139558550.htm)

fully_coded_incident_data.scite1: "Al Shabaab Attack In Garissa Police Base Leaves One Cop Dead, Another Injured," KahawaTungu, December 2, 2020.
fully_coded_incident_data.scite2: "Kenya police: Al-shabab militias attack a camp in Mandera," PRObserver.com, December 2, 2020.
fully_coded_incident_data.scite3: "Suspected al Shabaab Militants Attack Garissa Police Base," KenyaNews247.com, December 1, 2020.
fully_coded_incident_data.summary: 12/02/2020: Assailants opened fire on a police patrol base and launched a rocket-propelled grenade at the base’s armory in Fafi, Garissa, Kenya. An unknown number of officers were killed, one officer was wounded, and one other was reported missing. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
fully_coded_incident_data.weapdetail: Rocket-propelled grenades (RPGs) were used in the attack.

title: Shabaab raids military base in central Somalia
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144798248101</sequenceId>
			<id>43692130809</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Shabaab raids military base in central Somalia</title>
			<content>Photo released by Shabaab alleging to show its fighters briefly occupying the town of Bacaadweyne yesterday.  
In a large assault yesterday, Shabaab, al Qaeda’s branch in East Africa, raided a Somali military base in the town of Bacaadweyne in the central Mudug Region. 
 
According to local media reports, Shabaab militants clashed with Somali troops from the federal army’s 21st Division before moving into the adjacent town and briefly occupying it. 
 
Photos released by Shabaab today appear to corroborate the local reporting. The pictures show the jihadists moving into the base, capturing several vehicles and various weapons. Other photos then show the fighters walking around central Bacaadweyne unopposed. 
 
The pictures do not show any actual fighting, however, several dead Somali troops are shown inside the base. 
 
Voice of America’s Somali service added that the town was later recaptured by government forces after armed citizens joined in a counter-offensive against the jihadists. 
 
Casualty figures from yesterday’s fighting has varied widely. Voice of America reported that four Somali soldiers and 10 civilians involved in the counter-offensive were killed. 
 
Meanwhile, Mudug officials claimed that 12 members of Shabaab were killed. Other sources have indicated that at least 20 people were killed in total. 
 
For its part, Shabaab said it killed 53 soldiers and militiamen. In response, Somali military officials stated that their forces killed 50 jihadists in the fighting. An additional 6 militants were reportedly captured . 
 
Despite the discrepancies in casualty numbers, it is clear that Shabaab did in fact overrun the military base and town albeit only briefly. While most of its resources are invested in southern Somalia, the al Qaeda branch has shown it remains a potent threat across much of the country. 
 
Recent String of Attacks 
 
The raid in Bacaadweyne comes after a series of other recent Shabaab attacks across Somalia. 
 
Just before the Bacaadweyne raid yesterday, Shabaab was also responsible for an attack on the Turkish-trained Gorgor special forces unit in Lower Shabelle. That ambush occurred as Somali troops mounted an operation near Afgooye on the outskirts of Mogadishu. 
 
On Sunday, the jihadist group was also blamed for murdering an entire family in the southern Bakool Region. Shabaab did not comment on this series of purported executions. 
 
While on Nov. 27, a Shabaab suicide bomber detonated himself outside an ice cream parlor in Mogadishu killing at least 7 people. 
 
In its claim of responsibility, Shabaab said it was targeting a grouping of government officials. However, most reporting indicates the victims were civilians. 
 
On Nov. 24, 6 Somali soldiers from the US-trained Danab special forces unit were purportedly killed in an IED in the southern Lower Shabelle Region not far from the joint Somali-US base at Baledogle . 
 
A few days earlier on Nov. 17, Shabaab conducted another suicide bombing at a restaurant in Mogadishu which killed 5 civilians. 
 
And finally, on Nov. 6, Shabaab claimed it killed an American soldier in suicide bombing during a failed raid on the jihadists in the coastal city of  Gandershe. 
 
The United States has not commented on this claim, but on Nov. 26, the Central Intelligence Agency did admit one of its officers was recently killed in Somalia . It is possible that the officer was killed in the alleged Nov. 6 raid. 
 
With these recent attacks, Shabaab has conducted at least 29 suicide bombings inside Somalia since the beginning of 2020 according to data compiled by FDD’s Long War Journal . 
 
Despite some setbacks in recent years, Shabaab continues to be one of al Qaeda’s most effective branches. It maintains significant control over much of southern Somalia and retains the ability to strike in Mogadishu,  Kenya , and against heavily fortified bases in both Somalia and Kenya. 
 
Though its fortunes have ebbed and flowed over the past decade, it has weathered numerous offensives from an array of local, regional, and international actors, including the United States.

Caleb Weiss is a contributor to FDD's Long War Journal.

Tags:  Al Qaeda East Africa , Danab , Gorgor , Mudug , Shabaab , Somalia</content>

display_version: Shabaab raids military base in central Somalia Photo released by Shabaab alleging to show its fighters briefly occupying the town of Bacaadweyne yesterday. In a large assault yesterday, Shabaab, al Qaeda’s branch in East Africa, raided a Somali military base in the town of Bacaadweyne in the central Mudug Region. According to local media reports, Shabaab militants clashed with Somali troops from the federal army’s 21st Division before moving into the adjacent town and briefly occupying it. Photos released by Shabaab today appear to corroborate the local reporting. The pictures show the jihadists moving into the base, capturing several vehicles and various weapons. Other photos then show the fighters walking around central Bacaadweyne unopposed. The pictures do not show any actual fighting, however, several dead Somali troops are shown inside the base. Voice of America’s Somali service added that the town was later recaptured by government forces after armed citizens joined in a counter-offensive against the jihadists. Casualty figures from yesterday’s fighting has varied widely. Voice of America reported that four Somali soldiers and 10 civilians involved in the counter-offensive were killed. Meanwhile, Mudug officials claimed that 12 members of Shabaab were killed. Other sources have indicated that at least 20 people were killed in total. For its part, Shabaab said it killed 53 soldiers and militiamen. In response, Somali military officials stated that their forces killed 50 jihadists in the fighting. An additional 6 militants were reportedly captured . Despite the discrepancies in casualty numbers, it is clear that Shabaab did in fact overrun the military base and town albeit only briefly. While most of its resources are invested in southern Somalia, the al Qaeda branch has shown it remains a potent threat across much of the country. Recent String of Attacks The raid in Bacaadweyne comes after a series of other recent Shabaab attacks across Somalia. Just before the Bacaadweyne raid yesterday, Shabaab was also responsible for an attack on the Turkish-trained Gorgor special forces unit in Lower Shabelle. That ambush occurred as Somali troops mounted an operation near Afgooye on the outskirts of Mogadishu. On Sunday, the jihadist group was also blamed for murdering an entire family in the southern Bakool Region. Shabaab did not comment on this series of purported executions. While on Nov. 27, a Shabaab suicide bomber detonated himself outside an ice cream parlor in Mogadishu killing at least 7 people. In its claim of responsibility, Shabaab said it was targeting a grouping of government officials. However, most reporting indicates the victims were civilians. On Nov. 24, 6 Somali soldiers from the US-trained Danab special forces unit were purportedly killed in an IED in the southern Lower Shabelle Region not far from the joint Somali-US base at Baledogle . A few days earlier on Nov. 17, Shabaab conducted another suicide bombing at a restaurant in Mogadishu which killed 5 civilians. And finally, on Nov. 6, Shabaab claimed it killed an American soldier in suicide bombing during a failed raid on the jihadists in the coastal city of Gandershe. The United States has not commented on this claim, but on Nov. 26, the Central Intelligence Agency did admit one of its officers was recently killed in Somalia . It is possible that the officer was killed in the alleged Nov. 6 raid. With these recent attacks, Shabaab has conducted at least 29 suicide bombings inside Somalia since the beginning of 2020 according to data compiled by FDD’s Long War Journal . Despite some setbacks in recent years, Shabaab continues to be one of al Qaeda’s most effective branches. It maintains significant control over much of southern Somalia and retains the ability to strike in Mogadishu,  Kenya , and against heavily fortified bases in both Somalia and Kenya. Though its fortunes have ebbed and flowed over the past decade, it has weathered numerous offensives from an array of local, regional, and international actors, including the United States. Photos released by Shabaab reportedly from the raid in Bacaadweyne: Caleb Weiss is a contributor to FDD's Long War Journal. Are you a dedicated reader of FDD's Long War Journal? Has our research benefitted you or your team over the years? Support our independent reporting and analysis today by considering a one-time or monthly donation. Thanks for reading! You can make a tax-deductible donation here. Tags: Al Qaeda East Africa , Danab , Gorgor , Mudug , Shabaab , Somalia

title: At least four killed after massive hit-and-run in Trier, Germany
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144959039190</sequenceId>
			<id>43695121728</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>At least four killed after massive hit-and-run in Trier, Germany</title>
			<content>At least four people, including a baby, were killed on Tuesday in Trier, western Germany, and some 30 havebeen injured, some of them seriously, as a car, whose driver has been arrested, reports local media at high speed in a pedestrian zone.
The town's mayor, Wolfram Leibe, evoked a "crazy driver."
The car, a metallic grey SUV, circulated between 600 meters and a kilometer at high speed in this pedestrian zone, hitting everything in its path.
The death toll could increase further, according to a police spokesman, who said there were "several deaths."
At the moment the authorities do not confirm whether it is an attack, an accident or the product of a disturbed person.
Police, which have urged citizens to avoid the area while investigating this incident, while confirming on Twitter the arrest of the car driver, as well as the seizure of the vehicle.
He is a 51-year-old man from a town near Trier, which some German media identify as Bernd W.
Authorities also call for no speculation or photos and videos of the incident to be shared and has opened a channel for them to be sent directly to the police.
Despite this, there are already some images circulating on social media that show panic in the scene, tables and chairs on the floor and some destructions.
In addition to a truck attack on Berlin's Christmas market in 2016, with 12 dead, the worst attack on German soil, the self-proclaimed Islamic State group claimed a knife assassination in Hamburg, a bombing in Ansbach that wounded 15 people in which the aggressor died, and an axe attack on a train in Bavaria , with five wounded, in which the perpetrator was shot dead by the police.
Germany is also facing far-right terrorism, with several deadly shootings over the past two years,such as those that took place in Halle in Yom Kippur or Hanau, in February against two bars frequented by immigrants.
(With Euronews and RT information in Spanish)</content>

<article>

			<language>English</language>
			<title>AMP.- Afghanistan.- Several wounded in exploding a bomb as a vehicle from the Russian Embassy in Kabul</title>
			<content>MADRID, 1 (EUROPA PRESS)
   Several Russian diplomats were wounded on Tuesday after a bomb exploded as a vehicle from the Russian Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan's capital.


   As the Russian Foreign Ministry explained in a statement, several embassy employees have been slightly injured.
   The spokeswoman, Maria Zajarova, noted that during a vehicle journey of the Russian diplomatic mission on a road near the Embassy compound in Kabul she detonated "a homemade explosive device".
   According to preliminary reports, the target of the attack was a van by Afghan security forces moving in front of the diplomatic vehicle with soldiers inside.
   "We demand that Afghanistan conduct a thorough investigation of the incident and take the necessary measures to ensure the safety of russian representation personnel in Afghanistan," said Zajarova.
   In this regard, it detailed that the Russian Embassy in Kabul had put in place a number of additional measures aimed at increasing the security of diplomatic mission personnel and facilities.</content>

display_version:
Nexis® Metabase

AMP.- Afghanistan.- Several wounded in exploding a bomb as a vehicle from the Russian Embassy in Kabul

CE Noticias Financieras English

Publish Date: 01 Dec 2020 12:00

Length: 172 words


MADRID, 1 (EUROPA PRESS)
Several Russian diplomats were wounded on Tuesday after a bomb exploded as a vehicle from the Russian Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan's capital.


As the Russian Foreign Ministry explained in a statement, several embassy employees have been slightly injured.
The spokeswoman, Maria Zajarova, noted that during a vehicle journey of the Russian diplomatic mission on a road near the Embassy compound in Kabul she detonated "a homemade explosive device".
According to preliminary reports, the target of the attack was a van by Afghan security forces moving in front of the diplomatic vehicle with soldiers inside.
"We demand that Afghanistan conduct a thorough investigation of the incident and take the necessary measures to ensure the safety of russian representation personnel in Afghanistan," said Zajarova.
In this regard, it detailed that the Russian Embassy in Kabul had put in place a number of additional measures aimed at increasing the security of diplomatic mission personnel and facilities.

title: They threw another grenade, now against rubber tapper in "Cecilio Acosta", Maracaibo
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144960234720</sequenceId>
			<id>43695143603</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>They threw another grenade, now against rubber tapper in "Cecilio Acosta", Maracaibo</title>
			<content> 

A new grenade attack was recorded in Maracaibo and the affected commercial establishment is a rubber tapper located on Avenue 9 with Cecilio Acosta Street.



 


 

 

It happened around 12:10 p.m. on this first day in December 2020. Unofficially it was said that one of the aligners would have been injured. Some cars were hit by the expansive wave.

 


 

 

 

 

This criminal and terrorist action is number 14 so far this year. Extortion is undoubtedly still another headache for Zulians.

The bombings have taken place in Maracaibo, La Cañada de Urdaneta, Cabimas and Lagunillas.

 

Saying goodbye to the Zuliana region, where he served as head of Cicpc Zulia, Commissioner Carlos García acknowledged on November 6: "We applied new investigative methodologies to reduce the incidence of extortion crime, the main scourge affecting citizen peace."

 
                      
 </content>

Nexis® Metabase

They threw another grenade, now against rubber tapper in "Cecilio Acosta", Maracaibo

CE Noticias Financieras English

Publish Date: 01 Dec 2020 12:00

Length: 141 words


 

A new grenade attack was recorded in Maracaibo and the affected commercial establishment is a rubber tapper located on Avenue 9 with Cecilio Acosta Street.



 


 

 

It happened around 12:10 p.m. on this first day in December 2020. Unofficially it was said that one of the aligners would have been injured. Some cars were hit by the expansive wave.

 


 

 

 

 

This criminal and terrorist action is number 14 so far this year. Extortion is undoubtedly still another headache for Zulians.

The bombings have taken place in Maracaibo, La Cañada de Urdaneta, Cabimas and Lagunillas.

 

Saying goodbye to the Zuliana region, where he served as head of Cicpc Zulia, Commissioner Carlos García acknowledged on November 6: "We applied new investigative methodologies to reduce the incidence of extortion crime, the main scourge affecting citizen peace."

Police are investigating reported gunfire that happened Tuesday afternoon, according to the Lynchburg Police Department.

Several shots were fired in the 800 block of Brook Street, about two blocks away from Miller Park, according to police.

While no one was hurt, bullets hit multiple cars, as well as a home in the area.

"I heard 'pop, pop, pop, pop' and it scared the crap out of me. I walked outside, and there was nobody there. And I went to talk to the neighbors, and everybody else heard the same thing," said a neighbor, claiming she's heard gunshots four times in one month.

The scene is no longer active, according to police.

title: Africa.- Four crew members kidnapped by pirates on a tanker ship in the Gulf of Guinea
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144960890671</sequenceId>
			<id>43695154239</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Africa.- Four crew members kidnapped by pirates on a tanker ship in the Gulf of Guinea</title>
			<content>MADRID, 1 (EUROPA PRESS)
   Four crew members of a tanker ship have been kidnapped by pirates on the Gulf of Guinea, on the west central coast of the African continent, while travelling from republic of congo towards Togo.


   The tanker AGISILAOS, which was carrying petroleum derivatives, was attacked by pirates in the Gulf of Guinea on the night of November 29, on its way from Pointe Noire in the Republic of The Congo to Lomé, capital of Togo, as reported by the Maritime Bulletin news portal.
   The pirates kidnapped four crew members, including citizens of the Philippines, Romania and Russia, and escaped, while the rest of the crew is safe and the ship was finally able to reach Lomé.
   Hours before the attack, maritime security company Dryad Global's news portal reported an attempted attack by strangers in the Gulf on AGISILAOS, which was five nautical miles off the coast of Ghana, in ghanaian jurisdictional waters.
   According to the information provided by this means, the ship, which sailed under the Marshall Islands banner, attempted maneuvers to prevent the attackers from getting on board.
   Pirate activity in the Gulf of Guinea has intensified in recent months, where attacks have been on Benin and Nigerian waters in a short time ago, focusing mainly on merchant ships, mainly oil tankers and where there are no permanently prominent military units in the area to repel attacks.</content>

title: Philippine Police Kill Militant Linked To Deadly 2018 Cotabato Bombing
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144876594448</sequenceId>
			<id>43693745865</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Philippine Police Kill Militant Linked To Deadly 2018 Cotabato Bombing</title>
			<content>By Jeoffrey Maitem and Mark Navales

Philippine security forces on Tuesday killed a suspected member of an Islamic State-affiliated group who was linked to a 2018 bombing that left two people dead at a shopping mall, police said.

The suspect,Abraham Abad Abdulrahman (alias Abu Suffian), was gunned down during a pre-dawn raid at his home in southern Cotabato city, said Maj. Esmael Madin, the deputy police chief of the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao.

"Hepulled out a gun and opened fire against our cops," Madin told BenarNews. "They retaliated and killed him in the exchange."

An accomplice identified as Jasmiya Camsa Ibrahim escaped, Madin said, adding that officers recovered a .45-caliber pistol,a hand grenade and bomb-making materials from the hideout.

Abdulrahman was among suspects wanted in a bomb attack that killed two and injured 34 others at the South Seas Mall Complex in Cotabato on Dec. 31, 2018, Madin said.

The dead man worked under AbuTuraife, leader of the Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters (BIFF), according to officials. The BIFF split from the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), which had signed a peace deal with the government and controls the Bangsamoro autonomous region in the southern Philippines.

Turaifebroke away from the MILF chain-of-command to lead a few dozen followers. He is pushing for full independence on Mindanao Island, where Muslims are a large minority.

After pledging allegiance to Islamic State (IS), Turaife did not join the raid of the southern city of Marawi in 2017.

Last week, a suspected BIFF bomb maker,Abdul Rashid Lamalan, was killed by troops as he tried to smuggle an improvised bomb into the town of Isulan in nearby Sultan Kudarat province, said Col. Roy Galido, commander of the Army's 601st Infantry Brigade.

He said Lamalan died after he pulled a gun on officers at a police checkpoint.

"Army intelligence reports showed that Lamalan was linked to the Marawi siege and managed to escape along with other Abu Sayyaf terrorists," Galido said.

The Abu Sayyaf is a small group of militants based on the southern islands of Basilan and Jolo. It is known mostly for kidnappings, beheadings and bomb attacks.

An Abu Sayyaf commander, Isnilon Hapilon, had formed an alliance with IS and led militants from the Middle East and Southeast Asia in taking over Marawi in May 2017. They had planned to make the predominantly Muslim city the seat of their caliphate in the mostly Catholic Philippines.

Troops reclaimed the destroyed city five months later, after it was heavily bombed by government forces. As many as 1,200 people – mostly militants – died in the fighting.

The article Philippine Police Kill Militant Linked To Deadly 2018 Cotabato Bombing appeared first on Eurasia Review.</content>

title: Yemen.- At least two children killed and seven other civilians wounded in a bombing in Yemeni city of Taiz
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144962350860</sequenceId>
			<id>43695170471</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Yemen.- At least two children killed and seven other civilians wounded in a bombing in Yemeni city of Taiz</title>
			<content>MADRID, 1 (EUROPA PRESS)
   At least two children have been killed and seven other civilians wounded in an artillery shell attack on Monday in residential areas of The City of Taiz, Yemen, according to the United Nations.


   In a statement, the Office of the Resident Coordinator and humanitarian coordinator in Yemen, Lise Grande, has noted that three other children and four women are among the civilians wounded in the attack, which took place in the Usayfarah neighborhood of Al Qahira district.
   "These senseless attacks, with many casualties of children and women, are horrendous and inexcusable," condemned the representative of the World Health Organization (WHO) for Yemen, Altaf Musani, who has extended his condolences to the relatives of the deceased and wanted a "prompt and complete recovery" for the wounded. "Today, more families are afflicted by children who have died unnecessarily," he said.
   Hostilities in and around Taiz began to escalate in late September. UN partners have found the deaths of 55 civilians in October throughout the Eponymous Governorate, a similar figure to November.
   Artillery shell attacks in residential areas in the east of the city have increased, while armed clashes have taken place on surrounding fronts, increasing the death rates of civilians in the area.
   "Indiscriminate artillery shelling in residential areas has to stop," Musani has settled, while asking the parties involved in the Yemeni conflict to "distinguish between civilians and fighters."
   "Attacks on civilians are prohibited," he recalled, noting that recent bombings of Taiz "are violations of international humanitarian law."
   In this regard, Musani has censored that Yemen is facing increasing levels of humanitarian needs, with increasing rates of food insecurity and malnutrition, the COVID-19 pandemic, and an under-funded aid operation, so the focus should be on "saving lives."
   It has therefore urged all parties to the conflict to do their best to facilitate the humanitarian response and to commit themselves to stopping the violence.
   Another artillery shell attack on a village in The Governorate of Hodeida left at least five children and three women dead on Sunday, as well as three other children and three women injured, the United Nations reported.
   In this regard, UNICEF, which has raised the number of children killed in the two attacks to eleven, lamented that the "child slaughter is appalling." The UN agency, which has detailed that a one-month-old baby is among the deceased, has warned that "fact-checking is still ongoing, so the actual number of victims could be higher."
   "Children must be protected at all times," he said, urging all parties to the conflict to "respect" children and "keep them out of danger."
   Forces loyal to the Yemeni government, led by Abdo Rabbu Mansur Hadi and supported by Saudi Arabia, and the Iran-backed Huthi rebels have been fighting since late 2014, in a war now considered a power conflict between the region's two main rival powers.
   The conflict has led to what is the world's biggest humanitarian crisis. Today, nearly 80 percent of the population, some 24 million people, need assistance in the country, where there are more than 20 million in food insecurity.</content>

display_version:
MADRID, 1 (EUROPA PRESS)
At least two children have been killed and seven other civilians wounded in an artillery shell attack on Monday in residential areas of The City of Taiz, Yemen, according to the United Nations.


In a statement, the Office of the Resident Coordinator and humanitarian coordinator in Yemen, Lise Grande, has noted that three other children and four women are among the civilians wounded in the attack, which took place in the Usayfarah neighborhood of Al Qahira district.
"These senseless attacks, with many casualties of children and women, are horrendous and inexcusable," condemned the representative of the World Health Organization (WHO) for Yemen, Altaf Musani, who has extended his condolences to the relatives of the deceased and wanted a "prompt and complete recovery" for the wounded. "Today, more families are afflicted by children who have died unnecessarily," he said.
Hostilities in and around Taiz began to escalate in late September. UN partners have found the deaths of 55 civilians in October throughout the Eponymous Governorate, a similar figure to November.
Artillery shell attacks in residential areas in the east of the city have increased, while armed clashes have taken place on surrounding fronts, increasing the death rates of civilians in the area.
"Indiscriminate artillery shelling in residential areas has to stop," Musani has settled, while asking the parties involved in the Yemeni conflict to "distinguish between civilians and fighters."
"Attacks on civilians are prohibited," he recalled, noting that recent bombings of Taiz "are violations of international humanitarian law."
In this regard, Musani has censored that Yemen is facing increasing levels of humanitarian needs, with increasing rates of food insecurity and malnutrition, the COVID-19 pandemic, and an under-funded aid operation, so the focus should be on "saving lives."
It has therefore urged all parties to the conflict to do their best to facilitate the humanitarian response and to commit themselves to stopping the violence.
Another artillery shell attack on a village in The Governorate of Hodeida left at least five children and three women dead on Sunday, as well as three other children and three women injured, the United Nations reported.
In this regard, UNICEF, which has raised the number of children killed in the two attacks to eleven, lamented that the "child slaughter is appalling." The UN agency, which has detailed that a one-month-old baby is among the deceased, has warned that "fact-checking is still ongoing, so the actual number of victims could be higher."
"Children must be protected at all times," he said, urging all parties to the conflict to "respect" children and "keep them out of danger."
Forces loyal to the Yemeni government, led by Abdo Rabbu Mansur Hadi and supported by Saudi Arabia, and the Iran-backed Huthi rebels have been fighting since late 2014, in a war now considered a power conflict between the region's two main rival powers.
The conflict has led to what is the world's biggest humanitarian crisis. Today, nearly 80 percent of the population, some 24 million people, need assistance in the country, where there are more than 20 million in food insecurity.

title: Abductors demand N15m to free Edo teacher, wife
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144838708538</sequenceId>
			<id>43692959675</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Abductors demand N15m to free Edo teacher, wife</title>
			<content>Adeyinka Adedipe, Benin 

Kidnappers, who abducted a couple at Ewatto in the Esan South East Local Government Area of Edo State, have demanded N15m ransom for their release. 

Mr and Mrs Paul Aluola were kidnapped by armed men on Monday. 

Paul is said to be a teacher at the Iriwa Primary School, Ohordua, while his wife is a petty trader. 

A source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, disclosed that the kidnappers had called the couple’s family members for ransom, adding, “They are currently demanding N15m as ransom before releasing their victims. 

“The family members are wondering how a teacher can raise such an amount of money.” 

It was learnt that the couple were travelling on the Ewatto-Ubiaja Road and had approached the bridge on the Ellah River when the gunmen opened fire on the vehicle conveying them and forced it to stop. 

The kidnappers then dragged the victims out of the vehicle and took them into the bush. 

Academic activities at the Iriwa Primary School were reportedly paralysed on Tuesday due to the incident. 

When contacted, the state Commissioner of Police, Mr Johnson Kokumo; and the Police Public Relations Officer, SP Chidi Nwabuzor, did not take their calls.</content>

			<content>August 27, 2017 US Marines keep watch as unseen Afghan National Army soldiers participate in an IED (improvised explosive device) training exercise at the Shorab Military Camp in Lashkar Gah in the Afghan province of Helmand. Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg says there is danger in disorderly troop pull-out

Nato soldiers, such as these pictured in Torkham area near the Pakistan-Afghanistan in 2014, help train and advise Afghan forces. Reuters

Nato faces "hard decisions" in 2021 over ending its two-decade presence in Afghanistan, Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said.

Almost 2,000 US troops were withdrawn from the country last month.

Fewer than 12,000 soldiers from Nato countries remain in Afghanistan, mainly as trainers and advisers, but fears are rising that an unco-ordinated withdrawal could jeopardise stability.

Peace talks between the Taliban, which has demanded the withdrawal of Nato forces, and the Afghan government remain delicately poised, while violence persists across the country.

"As we continue to assess the situation in Afghanistan, it is clear that we will face a turning point early next year," Mr Stoltenberg said after an online meeting of Nato foreign ministers.

"If we stay, we risk continued fighting and an even longer-term engagement.

"If we leave, we risk Afghanistan once again becoming a safe haven for international terrorists and the loss of the gains made with such sacrifice.

"So there is a price for staying longer but there is also a price for leaving too soon.

"We will have to take some hard decisions when Nato defence ministers meet next February.

"But whatever we decide, we must do it in a co-ordinated and orderly way."

There has been a surge in violence in Afghanistan this year with often unrelenting Taliban attacks on the country's beleaguered security forces and the added threat of an ISIS presence.

The already disastrous humanitarian situation has been worsened by the Covid-19 pandemic.

About $12 billion in aid was pledged over the next four years at a conference last month, but much of it is tied to the progress of the peace talks.

German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas was also cautious about withdrawing too soon and said clear conditions must be set if there were to be further troop reductions.

"To safeguard what we have reached so far, we must not take any rash actions," Mr Maas said.

"This is why we call on the alliance to have a very close look at how far the conditions for a further withdrawal have been met to avoid sending a wrong message regarding the peace process."

Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg says there is danger in disorderly troop pull-out

Nato soldiers, such as these pictured in Torkham area near the Pakistan-Afghanistan in 2014, help train and advise Afghan forces. Reuters

Nato faces "hard decisions" in 2021 over ending its two-decade presence in Afghanistan, Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said.

Almost 2,000 US troops were withdrawn from the country last month.

Fewer than 12,000 soldiers from Nato countries remain in Afghanistan, mainly as trainers and advisers, but fears are rising that an unco-ordinated withdrawal could jeopardise stability.

Peace talks between the Taliban, which has demanded the withdrawal of Nato forces, and the Afghan government remain delicately poised, while violence persists across the country.

"As we continue to assess the situation in Afghanistan, it is clear that we will face a turning point early next year," Mr Stoltenberg said after an online meeting of Nato foreign ministers.

"If we stay, we risk continued fighting and an even longer-term engagement.

"If we leave, we risk Afghanistan once again becoming a safe haven for international terrorists and the loss of the gains made with such sacrifice.

"So there is a price for staying longer but there is also a price for leaving too soon.

"We will have to take some hard decisions when Nato defence ministers meet next February.

"But whatever we decide, we must do it in a co-ordinated and orderly way."

There has been a surge in violence in Afghanistan this year with often unrelenting Taliban attacks on the country's beleaguered security forces and the added threat of an ISIS presence.

The already disastrous humanitarian situation has been worsened by the Covid-19 pandemic.

About $12 billion in aid was pledged over the next four years at a conference last month, but much of it is tied to the progress of the peace talks.

German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas was also cautious about withdrawing too soon and said clear conditions must be set if there were to be further troop reductions.

"To safeguard what we have reached so far, we must not take any rash actions," Mr Maas said.

"This is why we call on the alliance to have a very close look at how far the conditions for a further withdrawal have been met to avoid sending a wrong message regarding the peace process."

title: Indonesia: Terrorists behind murder of 4 Christians, attack on Salvation Army post identified

<article>

			<title>Indonesia: Terrorists behind murder of 4 Christians, attack on Salvation Army post identified</title>
			<content>Muslim extremists with the terrorist group Eastern Indonesia Mujahideen (MIT) are believed to be responsible for the gruesome attack on The Salvation Army’s service post in central Sulawesi that left four Christians dead. 

According to International Christian Concern , on Nov. 27, Poso-based MIT militants Ali Kalora and Jaka Ramada, who pledge allegiance to the Islamic State, set fire to a church and burned down the homes of six churchgoers after they attacked the Lewonu Lembantongoa Service Post of The Salvation Army, slitting the throats of three Christians and beheading another. 

The leader of the outlawed Islamic group, Ali Kalora, was also seen at the scene of the crime. According to Yoga Priyautama, the chief of police in Sigi, a joint team has spread out and conducted searches in a number of areas that are suspected to be the killers’ escape routes. 

Following the attack, ICC followed up with local Christians to receive more information about the case. 

Survivors said that on the day of the murders, a Christian woman, Nei, was having breakfast with her husband, Yasa, when she saw approximately 10 unknown people visiting someone named Naka, who was at a nearby house in Tokelemo, Lembantongoa Village. 
 Free CP Newsletters  
Join over 250,000 others to get the top stories curated daily, plus special offers! 
   Free CP Newsletters  
Join over 250,000 others to get the top stories curated daily, plus special offers! 
  
Shortly thereafter, the terrorists entered Nei and Yasa’s home. They tied Yasa to a chair and then decapitated him with a machete and stabbed him in the back. His wife managed to escape after witnessing the killing, according to South China Morning Post . Some witnesses fled after seeing one of the MIT members near Yasa’s house. 

Naka and his son, Pedi, along with their house, were set on fire, while a fellow church member named Pinu was stabbed to death. In a previous report, ICC said they saw a video showing a charred victim being pulled from a pile of ruins, with smoke still rising in the background. 

“The fowler position of the body suggests the agony and pain endured by the victim before death.” 

Yasa’s son, Ulin, survived the attack and reported it to the police. The head of Lembantongoa village, Deki Basalulu, told Benar News that approximately 750 people fled their homes after the attack and took shelter at a safe location a few miles away. 

The  Salvation Army International confirmed  the attack on Saturday, saying that its building along with six homes of members were burned. 

Local Christians told ICC that MIT militants frequently interacted with the community, often asking for food from the church and the church fed them. The terrorists reportedly suspected that the community had informed police of their presence and therefore retaliated. 

However, Indonesian authorities have claimed that the attack was not religiously motivated and “merely an effort by the MIT to fulfill their goals and show their existence.” 

“This killing was not targeted at Christians,” Brigadier-General Farid Makhruf, commander of a military force that covered Central Sulawesi, claimed. “The victims were very unfortunate. The militants were likely to be looking for food and stumbled upon the villagers, and because it is very remote, it made them easy targets.” 

In a statement, Gina Goh, ICC’s regional manager for Southeast Asia, said that while ICC “appreciates the authorities for their swift actions to hunt down the perpetrators through the joint operation,” it is “disappointing to hear the official rhetoric that this attack was not motivated by religion and no church was burned down.” 

“Minority Christians in Indonesia have long suffered from discrimination and persecution and the Indonesian government should not cover the truth in the name of maintaining religious harmony,” she said. 

Over 80% of the population in Papua identifies as Christian, contrasting the predominantly Muslim Indonesia. Open Doors USA ranks Indonesia among the 50 countries where it is most difficult to be a Christian.

Indonesia: Terrorists behind murder of 4 Christians, attack on Salvation Army post identified

By

Leah MarieAnn Klett

, Christian Post Reporter

| Tuesday, December 01, 2020

Muslim extremists with the terrorist group Eastern Indonesia Mujahideen (MIT) are believed to be responsible for the gruesome attack on The Salvation Army’s service post in central Sulawesi that left four Christians dead.

According to International Christian Concern, on Nov. 27, Poso-based MIT militants Ali Kalora and Jaka Ramada, who pledge allegiance to the Islamic State, set fire to a church and burned down the homes of six churchgoers after they attacked the Lewonu Lembantongoa Service Post of The Salvation Army, slitting the throats of three Christians and beheading another.

The leader of the outlawed Islamic group, Ali Kalora, was also seen at the scene of the crime. According to Yoga Priyautama, the chief of police in Sigi, a joint team has spread out and conducted searches in a number of areas that are suspected to be the killers’ escape routes.

Following the attack, ICC followed up with local Christians to receive more information about the case.

Survivors said that on the day of the murders, a Christian woman, Nei, was having breakfast with her husband, Yasa, when she saw approximately 10 unknown people visiting someone named Naka, who was at a nearby house in Tokelemo, Lembantongoa Village.

Shortly thereafter, the terrorists entered Nei and Yasa’s home. They tied Yasa to a chair and then decapitated him with a machete and stabbed him in the back. His wife managed to escape after witnessing the killing, according to South China Morning Post. Some witnesses fled after seeing one of the MIT members near Yasa’s house.

Naka and his son, Pedi, along with their house, were set on fire, while a fellow church member named Pinu was stabbed to death. In a previous report, ICC said they saw a video showing a charred victim being pulled from a pile of ruins, with smoke still rising in the background.

“The fowler position of the body suggests the agony and pain endured by the victim before death.”

Yasa’s son, Ulin, survived the attack and reported it to the police. The head of Lembantongoa village, Deki Basalulu, told Benar News that approximately 750 people fled their homes after the attack and took shelter at a safe location a few miles away.

The Salvation Army International confirmed the attack on Saturday, saying that its building along with six homes of members were burned.

Local Christians told ICC that MIT militants frequently interacted with the community, often asking for food from the church and the church fed them. The terrorists reportedly suspected that the community had informed police of their presence and therefore retaliated.

However, Indonesian authorities have claimed that the attack was not religiously motivated and “merely an effort by the MIT to fulfill their goals and show their existence.”

“This killing was not targeted at Christians,” Brigadier-General Farid Makhruf, commander of a military force that covered Central Sulawesi, claimed. “The victims were very unfortunate. The militants were likely to be looking for food and stumbled upon the villagers, and because it is very remote, it made them easy targets.”

In a statement, Gina Goh, ICC’s regional manager for Southeast Asia, said that while ICC “appreciates the authorities for their swift actions to hunt down the perpetrators through the joint operation,” it is “disappointing to hear the official rhetoric that this attack was not motivated by religion and no church was burned down.”

“Minority Christians in Indonesia have long suffered from discrimination and persecution and the Indonesian government should not cover the truth in the name of maintaining religious harmony,” she said.

Over 80% of the population in Papua identifies as Christian, contrasting the predominantly Muslim Indonesia. Open Doors USA ranks Indonesia among the 50 countries where it is most difficult to be a Christian.

title: Former chamula mayor who expelled thousands of evangelicals are shot dead
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144963979958</sequenceId>
			<id>43695189842</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Former chamula mayor who expelled thousands of evangelicals are shot dead</title>
			<content>Elio HenríquezCorresponsal Newspaper La Jornada
Tuesday, December 1, 2020, p. 36
San Cristóbal de Las Casas, Chis., Domingo López Ruiz, former mayor of Chamula and one of the largest promoters of the expulsion of evangelical indigenous people in that municipality of Altos de Chiapas more than two decades ago, was shot dead, government sources were released.


They said that the former munícipe was killed on a five-hectare site that he had for 15 years in the Tzementé colony, municipality of Yajalón, in the north of the entity. Several percuted shell casings were found.
López Ruiz, 61, was a retired teacher; he was appointed interim mayor of Chamula in June 1993, following the resignation of Lorenzo Pérez Jolote, also a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI).
Pastor Esdras Alonso González, leader of the evangelical church Alas de Aguila, said that during his rule the expulsions of Chamula indians who had converted to Protestantism intensified.
According to various estimates, more than 30 thousand inhabitants of Chamula were expelled since the 1960s by traditionalist priist chieftains, on the grounds that they had become evangelical or related to the diocese of San Cristobal, then headed by Bishop Samuel Ruiz García.
He amassed 57 complaints; never investigated it
Alonso González recalled that in a year López Ruiz amassed 57 previous inquiries against him for offences related to expulsions (illegal deprivation of liberty, stripping, damage and others) and none were recorded by public prosecutors on the orders of the state government.
In interview, he added that they even had a recommendation from the National Commission on Human Rights (CNDH) blown up. It was a story of impunity."
He stated that on 5 July 1994, six months after the Zapatista armed uprising, López Ruiz was kidnapped by an armed evangelical group. For half a year 587 Chamula Protestants had been planted in the then Directorate of Indigenous Affairs, based in this city. The edil was released after two days.
In an interview published in La Jornada on February 20, 2006, Pérez Jolote, whose resignation gave way to the appointment of Domingo López Ruiz, recalled that after the kidnapping, he returned to govern the municipality, but was no longer the same. He was sad and weakened.</content>

Elio HenríquezCorresponsal Newspaper La Jornada
Tuesday, December 1, 2020, p. 36
San Cristóbal de Las Casas, Chis., Domingo López Ruiz, former mayor of Chamula and one of the largest promoters of the expulsion of evangelical indigenous people in that municipality of Altos de Chiapas more than two decades ago, was shot dead, government sources were released.


They said that the former munícipe was killed on a five-hectare site that he had for 15 years in the Tzementé colony, municipality of Yajalón, in the north of the entity. Several percuted shell casings were found.
López Ruiz, 61, was a retired teacher; he was appointed interim mayor of Chamula in June 1993, following the resignation of Lorenzo Pérez Jolote, also a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI).
Pastor Esdras Alonso González, leader of the evangelical church Alas de Aguila, said that during his rule the expulsions of Chamula indians who had converted to Protestantism intensified.
According to various estimates, more than 30 thousand inhabitants of Chamula were expelled since the 1960s by traditionalist priist chieftains, on the grounds that they had become evangelical or related to the diocese of San Cristobal, then headed by Bishop Samuel Ruiz García.
He amassed 57 complaints; never investigated it
Alonso González recalled that in a year López Ruiz amassed 57 previous inquiries against him for offences related to expulsions (illegal deprivation of liberty, stripping, damage and others) and none were recorded by public prosecutors on the orders of the state government.
In interview, he added that they even had a recommendation from the National Commission on Human Rights (CNDH) blown up. It was a story of impunity."
He stated that on 5 July 1994, six months after the Zapatista armed uprising, López Ruiz was kidnapped by an armed evangelical group. For half a year 587 Chamula Protestants had been planted in the then Directorate of Indigenous Affairs, based in this city. The edil was released after two days.
In an interview published in La Jornada on February 20, 2006, Pérez Jolote, whose resignation gave way to the appointment of Domingo López Ruiz, recalled that after the kidnapping, he returned to govern the municipality, but was no longer the same. He was sad and weakened.

title: Fire leaves 3.5 million people without television or radio in France
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144962267248</sequenceId>
			<id>43695169871</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Fire leaves 3.5 million people without television or radio in France</title>
			<content>Some 3.5 million people in southeastern France were left without television or radio on Tuesday after an arson attack the night before on a platform of the Télédiffusion de France (TDF) near Marseille.


"There is no doubt that the fire was arson," TDF Sud-Est regional director Patrice Bargas told AFP, evoking "traces of break-ins."
The fire broke out Monday night in the issuing room and spread through cables, local firefighters said, citing the possibility of an "intrusion" and a "malicious act." Meanwhile, an investigation has been opened by the Public Prosecutor's Office of Aix-en-Provence.
After the fire, the broadcast of 25 channels of TDT (Digital Terrestrial Television) of a total of 30, and 19 FM radio stations, was interrupted in a large neighborhood of the southeast of the territory, TDF said.
Channels TF1, LCP public-senate, TFX, Energie 12 and TMC continued.
The platform, whose façade featured black traces of smoke and flames, according to photographic records, also houses mobile phone relay antennas.
Customers of bouygues télécom, orange, free and sfr operators were affected, albeit to a lesser extent.
The television and radio antenna alone covers 2.6 million inhabitants and feeds other transmitters in the region, affecting an even larger population.
"This is one of our most important sites, a nerve center with a large coverage area due to its high position," patrice bargas said.
Installed in 1954 on top of a mountain surrounded by hiking trails, at an altitude of 600 meters, the platform is the most important in the southeast and the second largest in France.
In recent months, several 5G relay antennas have been burned in France, actions often carried out by ultra-leftist activists or opponents of 5G.</content>

title: Al-Shabab attack leaves dozens dead in Somalia
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144801246440</sequenceId>
			<id>43692190461</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Al-Shabab attack leaves dozens dead in Somalia</title>
			<content>A clash between al-Shabab militants, and Somali soldiers backed by civilians left dozens dead this week, the Ministry of Information said Tuesday.

The ministry told Voice of America that militants attacked a military base in the central town of Ba'adweyene on Monday morning, killing four soldiers and 11 civilians who took part in the battle.

Information Minister Osman Dubbe said government forces killed 51 al-Shabab militants in the fight, including the mastermind of the attack.

"Al-Shabab defeat in yesterday's attack in Ba'adweyene is a clear example of how the people who stand by the army can easily stop the attacks and plots of the enemy against the Somali nation, " Dubbe said.

Al-Shabab said it killed 53 troops in the attack and seized military vehicles. The group posted photos online of weapons it said it seized.</content>

At least 66 people, including four soldiers, 11 civilians, and 51 assailants, were killed in the ensuing clash. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident. (Review c3)

At least 66 people, including four soldiers, 11 civilians, and 51 assailants, were killed and at least six assailants were wounded in the ensuing clash. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

title: One killed as cultists clash in Delta community
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144838704907</sequenceId>
			<id>43692959696</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>One killed as cultists clash in Delta community</title>
			<content>Dele Ogunyemi and Matthew Ochei 

One person was feared dead, while many others sustained varying degrees of injury and no fewer than four buildings were razed down by rival cult members in Oteri community, Ughelli North Local Government Area of Delta State. 

Oteri, an agrarian community, is the hometown of the immediate past Secretary to the Delta State Government, Festus Agas. 

Eyewitnesses said trouble started on Sunday around 6.50pm when one Oghenero Oke, aka Last Card, was shot dead by gunmen believed to be members of the Aye Confraternity allegedly led by one Ejiata Elohor. 

It was gathered that the deceased, said to be a member of the Mafia Confraternity and also an indigene of the community, had an altercation with Elohor, alleged to be the leader of the rival Aye Confraternity in the area. 

The altercation, according to sources, was in connection with a relationship the deceased had with Elohor’s elder sister, which turned sour. 

It was gathered that the altercation became uncontrollable and subsequently turned violent. 

In the ensuing commotion, a house and shop belonging to Elohor’s parents were reportedly set ablaze by irate community youths sympathetic to Oghenero’s cause. 

In retaliation Oghenero was allegedly shot dead by a cult member loyal to Elohor. 

Community sources hinted that members of the Aye Confraternity had been having a running battle with the Aro  Baggers Confraternity, adding that Oghenero’s murder might snowball into a big battle between the rival groups. 

Meanwhile, Oghenero’s corpse has been deposited in the morgue of the Central Hospital, Ughelli, while one of those who sustained severe injuries is currently receiving treatment at the Ufor Hospital. 

A source, who spoke to journalists on condition of anonymity, fingered a notable youth and a member of the vigilante group in the area as leading the gang of cultists, who set ablaze the building belonging to the father of a former Resident Electoral Commissioner in the old Bendel State, Chief Atuyota Ejughemre. 

The fear of possible reprisal was heightened in the community on Tuesday as security operatives were seen patrolling the streets. 

The state Police Public Relations Officer, DSP Onome Onovwakpoyeya, confirmed the incident but denied the burning of houses. 

“Yes, one person was killed but no house was burnt, according to the DPO in Ughelli. Right now, there is intensive police patrol at Ughelli,” she stated.</content>

<article>
			<sequenceId>1144952186162</sequenceId>
			<id>43695010455</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>UN Security Council denounces terrorist attacks on civilians in northeastern Nigeria</title>
			<content>Dubai: Emirates News Agency has issued the following news release:

The members of the United Nations Security Council on Monday strongly condemned the killing of civilians in northeast Nigeria.

In a press statement, the council members condemned 'in the strongest terms' the terrorist attacks that occurred in northeast Nigeria on Saturday, in which scores of civilians were reportedly killed and many others injured or abducted.

They expressed their deepest sympathy and condolences to the families of the victims and to the government of Nigeria, reaffirming that terrorism in all its forms and manifestations constitutes one of the most serious threats to international peace and security.</content>

			<title>Youth Shot At By Gunmen In Srinagar</title>
			<content>Srinagar: A 24-year-old youth on Tuesday was critically injured after unknown gunmen fired upon him in Soura area of this capital city.

Unidentified militants fired upon a man identified as Nadif Khan son of Muhammad Hanief Khan of Bilal colony Soura, leaving him critically injured, said a senior police officer. The injured youth, he said was immediately rushed to SKIMS for treatment.

Medical Superintendent SKIMS Dr. Farooq Jan said that the youth has firearm injury and his condition was serious.

Meanwhile, the area has been cordoned off to nab the attackers.</content>

title: Ten women and children killed in shelling in Yemen
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144964084644</sequenceId>
			<id>43695190670</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Ten women and children killed in shelling in Yemen</title>
			<content>Seven children and three women were killed and dozens of others injured in shelling of Houthi rebels in residential areas of Yemen in the past two days, local sources reported to the AFP on Tuesday.


The bombings occurred in districts of Taiz, southwest, and Al-Durayhimi, in the coastal region of Hodeida (west).
The "crime was committed by the Houthis" during attacks on a government-controlled neighborhood, local sources said. The rebels did not comment on it.
The Doctors Without Borders (MSF) oenegé in Yemén called on Twitter "all armed groups respect international humanitarian law and take all necessary precautions to avoid civilian casualties."
"This attack on women and children is unacceptable and unjustifiable," Altaf Musani, responsible for United Nations humanitarian aid in Yemen, said in a statement.
The conflict in Yemen has since 2014 confronted government forces recognized by the international community, supported by Saudi Arabia, with Houthi rebels, supported by Iran and who have taken control of a part of the territory, including the capital Of Allah.

The "crime was committed by the Houthis" during attacks on a government-controlled neighborhood, local sources said. The rebels did not comment on it.

"This attack on women and children is unacceptable and unjustifiable," Altaf Musani, responsible for United Nations humanitarian aid in Yemen, said in a statement.
The conflict in Yemen has since 2014 confronted government forces recognized by the international community, supported by Saudi Arabia, with Houthi rebels, supported by Iran and who have taken control of a part of the territory, including the capital Of Allah.

title: Germany bans a neo-Nazi group
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144963973561</sequenceId>
			<id>43695189773</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Germany bans a neo-Nazi group</title>
			<content>Germany declared out of law a far-right neo-Nazi group, called "Sturmbrigade 44," for promoting hatred, Home Horst Seehofer announced on Tuesday.


According to the minister, this group also known as "Wolfsbrigade 44", "sows hatred" and "advocates the restoration of a Nazi state".
"Anyone trying to undermine the fundamental values of our liberal society will face the determined reaction of the constitutional state," Seehofer said in a statement.
Members of the group -- which police seized white weapons and crossbows, as well as Nazi flags in several German states -- "clearly expressed support for Adolf Hitler," according to the minister, who added that they were characterized by their "military attire and appearance," "pronounced racism" and "inhumane ideology."
By July 2019, police had searched several apartments in different federal states that belonged to this group, which was founded in 2016.
Last November, federal prosecutors prosecuted 12 far-right people accusing them of conspiring to commit "terrorist attacks" against politicians, asylum seekers and Muslims.
Last February, a man in favor of racist and anti-Semitic theories killed ten people of foreign origin in Hanau, east of Frankfurt.

title: Esperon: Daughter of leftist solon victim, not martyr, of NPA
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1145379555588</sequenceId>
			<id>43703489330</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Esperon: Daughter of leftist solon victim, not martyr, of NPA</title>
			<content>Jevilyn Cullamat, daughter of a left-wing member of the House of Representatives, was a victim not a martyr, according to National Security Adviser Hermogenes Esperon Jr. on Tuesday (Dec. 1).

While expressing sympathy for the death of Jevilyn, daughter of Bayan Muna Rep. Eufemia Cullamat, Esperon said Jevilyn 'lost her life for a forsaken cause.'

Esperon said Jevilyn, who was killed in Surigao del Sur in a clash between New People's Army (NPA) and the military, was meted the death sentence as soon as she joined NPA, which Esperon said had been condoned by her family.

'Jevilyn was not a martyr,' said Esperon, armed forces chief of staff of former President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

'She was deceived into sacrificing her life for a cause lacking any noble purpose,' he said in a statement.

Esperon said Jevilyn's death has been 'politicized' and 'romanticized.'

Jevilyn, whom soldiers tagged as NPA medic, was a 'victim of a manipulative organization that has taken advantage of her from the moment she was radicalized until her recruitment into the armed struggle,' Esperon said.

Representative Cullamat earlier hailed her daughter as hero of the lumad, who joined NPA because of continuing military abuse of lumad communities

Esperon said the lawmaker showed she lacked remorse over the death of her daughter in the company of guerrillas.

'It pains me that even in her daughter's death, Representative Cullamat cannot show remorse and has gone so far as extolling the false advocacy and political agenda of the armed revolution,' Esperon said.

He said other relatives of Jevilyn were also members of NPA and involved in criminal cases, like kidnapping and murder.

'We see the deep-rooted radicalization of the extended Cullamat family and the exploitation of the indigenous peoples' community,' Esperon said.

He called on NPA backers to ponder on their support for the armed revolution which, he said, 'has claimed the lives of thousands of Filipinos.'</content>

title: Rampaging Suspected Cultists Kill One, Raze Houses In Delta Community
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1145379739621</sequenceId>
			<id>43703491314</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Rampaging Suspected Cultists Kill One, Raze Houses In Delta Community</title>
			<content>Rampaging suspected cultists have killed one person, injured scores and razed houses in Oteri community, Ughelli, Delta State.

The community it was learnt on Tuesday, is licking its wounds after the rampaging cultists left in their wake a tale of blood, sorrow and tears with no fewer than four buildings burnt.

The incident, it was gathered, occurred on Sunday, November 29, 2020, at about 6:50 pm.

It was gathered that trouble started when one Oghenero Oke, also known as Last Card, was shot and killed by a group of gunmen believed to be members of Aye confraternity.

The victim, who is a member of Mafia confraternity and also an indigene of the community, was said to have had an altercation with one Elohor over the relationship he had with Elohor's elder sister which had turned sour.

Although reasons for the carnage were still sketchy, the house and shop belonging to the parents of Elohor were one of the houses reportedly burnt down.

It will be recalled that members of the Aye confraternity have been in a sustained battle with the Aro Baggers confraternity.

Meanwhile, efforts were said to be ongoing by the leadership of the community to fish out the perpetrators who are currently at large.

The corpse of the deceased has been reportedly deposited at the Central Hospital mortuary in Ughelli, while those with severe injuries are said to be receiving treatment at one Ufor Hospital.

As of the time of filing this report, the fear of possible reprisals has heightened in the community as security operatives patrol the community.

Confirming the incident, Police Public Relations Officer (PPRO), Delta Police Command, Onome Onovwakpoyeya, a Deputy Superintendent of Police (DSP), confirmed the incident but added that no house was burnt.

Oteri community is the country home of the immediate past secretary to the Delta State Government (SSG), Festus Ovie Agas.</content>

title: (CITY): Youth shot dead in Nawa Killi

			<language>English</language>
			<title>(CITY): Youth shot dead in Nawa Killi</title>
			<content>A youth was shot dead in Abbas Durrani Scheme area of Nawa Killi on Tuesday. 

According to rescue sources, unidentified armed men killed one person Ali Muhammad, 23, son of Amir Hamza Achakzai, a resident of Spiny Road Pushtunbagh in Abbas Durrani Scheme area of Nawa Killi. 

The body was shifted to Sandeman Provincial Hospital Quetta, however, motive behind the murder could not be ascertained till filing this report.</content>

(CITY): Youth shot dead in Nawa Killi

Pakistan Press International

Publish Date: 01 Dec 2020 12:00

Length: 69 words

A youth was shot dead in Abbas Durrani Scheme area of Nawa Killi on Tuesday.

According to rescue sources, unidentified armed men killed one person Ali Muhammad, 23, son of Amir Hamza Achakzai, a resident of Spiny Road Pushtunbagh in Abbas Durrani Scheme area of Nawa Killi.

The body was shifted to Sandeman Provincial Hospital Quetta, however, motive behind the murder could not be ascertained till filing this report.

title: Zabarmari: Civilian JTF Recovers 35 More Bodies, Confirmed Death Toll Now 78
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1145379715878</sequenceId>
			<id>43703491449</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Zabarmari: Civilian JTF Recovers 35 More Bodies, Confirmed Death Toll Now 78</title>
			<content>Troops and operatives of the Civilian Joint Task Force (CJTF) have recovered at least 35 decomposing bodies in the Zabarmari area of Jere, Borno State Northeast Nigeria, on Monday.

These are different from the 43 originally reported to have been killed by terrorists, taking the confirmed death toll to 78.

The search operation for the remaining victims of Saturday's gruesome massacre was initially planned for Sunday, security sources informed HumAngle.

The newly discovered victims were buried at the spot because the search team was unable to move the badly decapitated and decomposing bodies.

HumAngle had reported after the Saturday gruesome murder of the 43 rice farmers that many more farmers were still missing while the death toll was expected to rise.

A member of the civilian vigilante group had on Sunday told our reporter dozens of farmers were still missing. He said a search and rescue exercise for survivors and other deceased victims remained a dangerous task as Boko Haram fighters operated a few kilometres from Zabarmari general area.

Zabarmari is located less than 20 kilometres from the Counter-Insurgency Operation Lafiya Dole command centre in Maiduguri, the state capital.

On Sunday, 43 victims of the massacre were buried with the state governor Babagana Zulum present. Zulum provided financial assistance to some of the survivors and bereaved families.

The attackers had tied and slaughtered their victims and also burnt the farm they were cultivating.

According to the United Nations (UN), at least 110 people were killed during the attack. Several women are also believed to have been kidnapped.

Edward Kallon, the UN's humanitarian coordinator in Nigeria, said the incident was the most violent direct attack against innocent civilians this year. He urged that the perpetrators of the 'heinous and senseless act' be brought to justice.

The killings have sparked public outcry, with many people calling on the government to intensify efforts to improve security in the country.

In a statement issued on Monday, the US Embassy in Nigeria asked the Federal Government to unravel the killers of the slain farmers, adding that they should be brought to book.

'The United States condemns in the strongest terms the November 28 violent attack in Borno, Nigeria. The United States offers our deepest condolences to the families and friends of those killed or kidnapped,' the statement read.</content>

title: One killed, four buildings raised down, by suspected cultists in Delta
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1145378793554</sequenceId>
			<id>43703477562</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>One killed, four buildings raised down, by suspected cultists in Delta</title>
			<content>At least four buildings were raised down by fire and one person killed by suspected rival cults last Sunday in Oteri community, Ughelli North local government area of Delta state

It was learnt that the trouble started when one Oghenero Oke with nickname Last Card was shot dead by suspected gunmen believed to be members of AYE Confraternity led by the leader of the group.

The late One whom they said was a member of Mafia Confraternity until his death had had an issue with one of the leaders of the Aye Confraternity following a relationship late Oke was into with the leader's elder sister.

It was gathered that it was late Oke's death that led to the shooting and raising down of the building and shop belonging to the parents of one of the leaders of the Aye confraternity by irate youths from the community.

It would be recalled that members of the Aye confraternity have been in a running battle with the Aro baggers confraternity about 3 weeks ago and this incident may further cause crisis between the Aye and Mafia confraternities.

A source who pleaded anonymity said efforts are ongoing by the leadership of the Community to fish out the perpetrators who are currently at large, while the corpse of the deceased has been deposited at the Central Hospital mortuary in Ughelli.

Security personnel have been drafted to the area and every part of Ughelli to calm the tension and fear of possible reprisal in the community since weekends till date.

A Police source in A Division Police station confirmed the incident and said they are on top of the matter.</content>

title: Senate condoles with solon for death of daughter killed in clash with ARMED FORCES OF THE PHILIPPINES
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1145379621089</sequenceId>
			<id>43703490053</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Senate condoles with solon for death of daughter killed in clash with ARMED FORCES OF THE PHILIPPINES</title>
			<content>Ahead of a hearing into alleged red-tagging by military officials, the Senate on Tuesday expressed its condolences to Bayan Muna Rep. Eufemia Cullamat for the death of her daughter, who was slain in a clash between between government soldiers and the New People's Army (NPA).

'On behalf of the Senate, I'd like to express our deepest condolences and sympathy to Bayan Muna Rep. Cullamat for the loss of her daughter Jevilyn,' Senate President Vicente Sotto III said before the Senate defense committee began its third hearing on red-tagging.

'Our thoughts and prayers are with you and your entire family. May your beautiful memories sustain and bring comfort to you during this difficult time,' he added.

According to the Philippine Army, Jevilyn, who allegedly serves as a medic for the NPA, was killed in an encounter with the Philippine Army's 3rd Special Forces Battalion (3SFBn) last November 28.

'As far as we are concerned, a dead NPA rebel or a dead soldier is only as bad and tragic as a dead Filipino for we see no difference except probably the cause that they had fought and died for,' Senator Panfilo Lacson, chair of the Senate defense panel, said.</content>

Ahead of a hearing into alleged red-tagging by military officials, the Senate on Tuesday expressed its condolences to Bayan Muna Rep. Eufemia Cullamat for the death of her daughter, who was slain in a clash between between government soldiers and the New People's Army (NPA).

'On behalf of the Senate, I'd like to express our deepest condolences and sympathy to Bayan Muna Rep. Cullamat for the loss of her daughter Jevilyn,' Senate President Vicente Sotto III said before the Senate defense committee began its third hearing on red-tagging.

'Our thoughts and prayers are with you and your entire family. May your beautiful memories sustain and bring comfort to you during this difficult time,' he added.

According to the Philippine Army, Jevilyn, who allegedly serves as a medic for the NPA, was killed in an encounter with the Philippine Army's 3rd Special Forces Battalion (3SFBn) last November 28.

'As far as we are concerned, a dead NPA rebel or a dead soldier is only as bad and tragic as a dead Filipino for we see no difference except probably the cause that they had fought and died for,' Senator Panfilo Lacson, chair of the Senate defense panel, said.

title: Israeli Soldiers Abduct Eleven Palestinians In West Bank
raw_feed_version:
<article>
			<sequenceId>1144551485487</sequenceId>
			<id>43687241717</id>
			<language>English</language>
			<title>Israeli Soldiers Abduct Eleven Palestinians In West Bank</title>
			<content>Israeli soldiers abducted, on Tuesday at dawn, eleven Palestinians from their homes in several parts of the occupied West Bank, after the soldiers invaded many communities, searched and ransacked homes, the Palestinian Prisoners’ Society (PPS) has reported. 
 
The PPS said the soldiers abducted Moath Ka’bi, and Nidal Khalaf al-Haj Mohammad, from their homes, and added that Nidal is the brother of Monther, a political prisoner who was sentenced by Israel to thirty years in prison. 
 
In occupied Jerusalem, the soldiers abducted a former political prisoner and a student at Birzeit University, identified as Bakr Oweiss, in addition to Montaser Barbar, the son of Majd Barbar, who is also a political prisoner serving a 20-year sentence, in addition to Faisal Luay, from the al-‘Isawiya town. 
 
The soldiers also abducted Ayman Abu Eid, Hashem Hmeidan, Ziad Taha, Jouda Houshiyya and Sharif Khdour, from the towns of Biddu and Qotna, near Jerusalem. 
 
In Salfit, in central West Bank, the soldiers abducted Rawdi Ma’zouz Yassin, from his home. 
 
In related news, the soldiers invaded the al-Khader town, south of Bethlehem, and summoned Ahmad Salah for interrogation in the nearby Etzion military base and security center. 
 
It is worth mentioning that Salah is a former political prisoner, who was only released a few months ago, after spending 11 years in Israeli prisons.</content>
